Situation1: A life-support device in the intensive care unit is flashing critical fault codes.
Expectation2: Live according to Christian moral values and ethics
Situation2: They try to keep moral values in mind during everyday routines
Story: The alarm blared as I rushed into the ICU, my toolbox clattering at my side. The nurse’s face was pale—one of the life-support machines was flashing red, its screen filled with cryptic fault codes. As a machine repairer, I was expected to diagnose and fix the issue immediately; a patient’s life depended on it. My hands moved quickly, but my mind was tangled. The hospital’s policy required me to log every repair, but I noticed the previous technician had skipped a crucial safety check. Reporting it would mean he could lose his job, but ignoring it would compromise my integrity as a Christian, who is called to be honest and just. The weight of both roles pressed on me: the urgency to save a life, and the call to uphold truth and compassion. My heart pounded as I stared at the machine, torn between the demands of my profession and the values of my faith, knowing that whatever I chose would have consequences.
